title: 111_s591
content:
The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for these purposes. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission to evaluate potential improvements in the approach to high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel management, and to submit a report to Congress with findings and recommendations for the management of various types of radioactive waste. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with committee chairs. Appointees must meet specific qualifications. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with committee chairs. Appointees must meet specific qualifications, including not being engaged in high-level radioactive waste activities under contract with the Department of Energy and being prominent United States citizens with expertise in relevant fields. All members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission, consisting of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, will have a Chairperson appointed under subsection (a)(5). The Commission will begin operations promptly after enactment, with meetings called by the Chairperson or majority members. A quorum of five members is required, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibilities to a Government corporation, providing funding for waste management, cost-sharing options with private industry, and establishing interim storage facilities. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for spent nuclear fuel management, including establishing interim storage facilities, advancing fuel cycle technologies, and transferring fuel inventories to the Department of Energy. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for spent nuclear fuel management, including interim storage facilities, deep geologic disposal, and additional management approaches. They consult with various stakeholders to carry out their duties effectively. The Commission will consult with stakeholders, submit recommendations on existing fees, and analyze financial impacts for a final report to Congress as required by the Act. The Commission will consult with stakeholders, submit recommendations on existing fees, and analyze financial impacts for a final report to Congress as required by the Act. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths. It can also enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. The Commission can request information from federal agencies in a timely manner and must handle and disseminate it according to applicable laws. Federal agencies, including the General Services Administration, can provide administrative support and services to the Commission. The Commission may request assistance from federal departments and agencies, including services, funds, facilities, staff, and support services as authorized by law. Additionally, the Commission can utilize postal services like other federal government entities. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and staff provisions are outlined. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain federal employment rules. The staff director and personnel are considered federal employees for specific purposes under title 5 of the United States Code. The Commission can appoint staff and set their compensation without following federal employment rules. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges. The Commission can also procure expert services at specified rates. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION; TRAVEL EXPENSES.

Each Commission member may receive compensation not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a level IV position under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties.

SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. The Federal agencies will cooperate with the Commission to provide appropriate security clearances to members and staff. No access to classified information will be granted without the necessary clearances. SEC. 11. REPORTS. The Commission will release an interim report for public comment within a year and a final report to Congress within two years. The final report will include agreed-upon findings, dissenting opinions, and public feedback. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds necessary for implementing this Act are authorized to be appropriated. SEC. 13. TERMINATION. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out this Act. SEC. 13. TERMINATION. The Commission's authority ends 180 days after the final report submission. During this period, the Commission can conclude its activities and disseminate the final report.
